Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Situation2: They coordinate closely with contractors to keep the construction schedule on track.
Story: I glance at my phone, a text from Alex lighting up the screen: “Which night this week for our date? I’m free whenever you are.” My heart lifts—finally, a stretch of evenings where we both aren’t buried in work. I want to say yes to all of them, to make up for the rushed dinners and missed weekends. But as I open my calendar, my architect’s mind kicks in. The contractor just emailed; the steel delivery is delayed, and if I don’t coordinate a workaround tonight, the whole project could slip. My team expects me to be on top of every detail, to keep things moving no matter what. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing in—Alex’s hope for time together, my responsibility to the project. I stare at the calendar, torn between the promise I made to Alex and the silent demand of the construction site, my thumb hovering over the reply button, heart pounding with indecision.
